lo_what.name: Accessibility is about making technology “usable by everyone, regardless of their abilities or disabilities”*
lo_what.arg: This is important to web development because... (LO argument)
lo_what.material:
*(http://teachaccess.org/about/).

“People have all kinds of ability. If you design without accounting for variation in ability, your design will fail. Designs that account for all abilities are called accessible designs.” (Andy Ko)

According to the World Health Organization,

“Disability is not just a health problem. It is a complex phenomenon, reflecting the interaction between features of a person’s body and features of the society in which he or she lives.”

To put this more concretely, not being able to hear your conversational partner is no hindrance if you are speaking to each other in sign language.

lo_kinds.name: There are many different kinds of abilities and disabilities
lo_kinds.arg: This is important to web development because... (LO argument)
lo_kinds.material:
One way to convey the wide range of abilities and disabilities is to show students examples in different categories:

Vision

  • Blind
  • Low-Vision
  • Color Blind

Hearing

  • Deaf
  • Hard of Hearing

Speech

  • Ability to speak
  • Speed impediments

Mobility

  • Ability to walk
  • Ability to use limbs

Cognitive

  • Dyslexia, dysgraphia, dyscalculia
  • ADHD
  • Memory loss
  • Learning disabilities

Behavioral

  • Bipolar

Another is to share statistics on their prevalence:

  • About 1 in 7 worldwide have a disability
  • More than 15% of K12 students have a disability (Source: Reports of IEP and Section 504 accommodations from U.S. public schools.)
  • Table of percentages from U.S. Census Bureau from 2002:

To illustrate how these (dis)abilities can be situational, temporary, and permanent, this graphic may help (source: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/design/inclusive). The graphic doesn’t include cognitive impairments, but being tired or drunk would be a situational variant, while chronic sleep deprivation (due to being a new parent for example) would be temporary, whereas dyslexia or Down syndrome are permanent.

The following anecdote shows why the concept of an “average” person can be misleading:

In 1950 the US Air Force was trying to figure out how to redesign airplane cockpits to reduce accidents, and decided to take over 4000 pilots and average their measurements along 140 different metrics, such as thumb length, crotch height, and the distance from a pilot’s eye to his ear, in order to design a cockpit to better fit the average pilot. However, one of their scientists had doubts about this method, so he chose ten metrics that he thought would be most important for the design, generously defined average to be in the middle 30% around the mean for each of the ten dimensions, and found that not one of the measured pilots fit those criteria. Even if he only chose three dimensions, only 3.5% of pilots were “average.”

lo_kinds_viz.name: There are many different kinds of abilities and disabilities
lo_kinds_viz.material:
Despite the “visual” in visualization, creative visualizations can take many forms as anyone who’s been to a science museum with interactive exhibits can testify. Thus, a visualization might rely on any of the following abilities, so they should be taken into account. Conversely, keeping them in mind might also help to design a visualization specifically for the benefit of people with a certain disability.

lo_sr.name: Screen readers read structured "documents" as speech
material: "Documents" includes things we think of as documents (mostly text, maybe some headings and images) but also more complicated things like web pages or user interfaces
Screen readers expose structure (headings, lists, menus, etc) in different ways which often enable easier navigation to desired content
Expert screen reader users form their own ways of using them (e.g. at high playback speeds) that are not necessarily comparable to novice screen reader users
(testing something yourself is different from having an expert screen reader user do it)
(video demo for them or students?)
lo_sr.arg: Screen readers are a common way that blind or low-vision people interact with the web, so it's good for students to know about them. Since they're ubiquitous, they can also be used as a demo, and to introduce the idea of serving everyone.

lo_struct_word.name: Specify and expose as much structural metadata as possible in word documents
material: Use a document editor's styles in order to organize sections and subsections
Use a document editor's lists (ordered or unordered) instead of making your own equivalent
Set alt text for your images (this provides a textual description for anyone who can't see them--more on how to do good ones later)
lo_struct_word.arg: Word, Google Docs, and other similar software provide a common way to share information. There are a few simple but key tricks to expose document structure to screen readers, some of which also provide benefits beyond accessibility concerns.

lo_struct_html.name: Specify and expose as much structural metadata as possible in HTML documents
material: Use heading tags to structure sections and subsections
Use list tags (ordered or unordered) instead of making your own equivalent
Use table heading tags to provide information about the structure of information in a table
<table> comes with tr/td/th
Fancier things possible if a header spans multiple rows or cols: https://www.washington.edu/accesscomputing/tip-8-markup-tables-appropriately
In general, use the most specific HTML tag to your situation (e.g. use <button> instead of a <div> styled to act like a button)
This also adds a button to a tab order for keyboard navigation purposes, so it's not just for people with screen readers
If that's not possible, set the "role" attribute of a tag
Even if there isn't a specific HTML tag, there may be a role attribute that fits anyway (e.g. role="search" for a search widget)
Roles are part of WAI-ARIA (Web Accessibility Initiative, Accessible Rich Internet Applications) (link to accessibility standards/ARIA)
lo_struct_html.arg: HTML is one of the best ways to provide accessible documents when used correctly, since the tags it uses to mark up the information it represents can also be used to understand a pages structure. This page provides some examples, beyond more readable and easier-to-understand code, to use core features of the language rather than reinventing the wheel.

lo_pdf.name: PDFs are difficult to make accessible and other formats should be used where possible
material: The original intention of the pdf format was to preserve a fixed visual representation
As such, PDFs often discard structural information (headings, text order, etc) or even the fact that text is text

In order to link the structure of the pdf as metadata that a screen reader can perceive, a pdf must be tagged (tag is used here in the sense it has in HTML, where tags can automatically provide metadata about their content)
MS Word can export a tagged PDF on Windows, although often post-processing is required to correct errors such as text order around images
The professional version of Adobe Reader can be used to manually check for and adjust tags
A more specific pipeline can be found here if you ever need to do this process: (link)
lo_pdf.arg: PDFs are a common way to share information since they preserve a fixed visual representation and can be opened on any operating system. However, students should understand their drawbacks when it comes to accessibility, and how to make them accessible if they are constrained to use them.

lo_gp.name: The HTML standard includes ways to group input fields with labels so that they're associated together
material: Why? In forms, this exposes information usually encoded in the visual layout (e.g. by always having a label for an input field directly above it) to someone who can't see the screen.
To do this:
Enclose the input field in a <label> tag
Use aria-labelledby and for attributes (?)
Also add an extra aria-label when format is so visually obvious, e.g. three fields for telephone number, that it doesn't need a label visible to everyone
aria-described-by (when a label is insufficient, so a field is also associated with e.g. extra help text)
Do make sure labels are meaningful and unique, but they shouldn't be too verbose
In general, grouping is also helpful if it makes sure a caption gets associated with the image its for
[Provide checkbox/radio buttons example]
lo_gp.arg: This exposes students to a different way in which HTML markup can be used for non-obvious but useful tasks. Grouping in this way is an important concept because it forces students to reconsider the assumption that visual organization is all the organization that is needed.

lo_mob_frame.name: Frameworks and accessibility
lo_mob_frame.material: All mobile development frameworks have accessibility built into them, but developer effort is required in order to make sure a specific application is compatible with those frameworks. Going off and making your own solution can often lead to an inaccessible app. One paper that investigates the interplay between frameworks and other sources of (in)accessibility in mobile apps is by Ross et al.

lo_vis_obj.name: Object recognition
lo_vis_obj.material: When it comes to computer vision, most people think first of object recognition. One main accessibility application is in automatically generating alt text for images on the web, so screen readers have some content to read aloud to blind or low-vision users. A more complex variant would be to generate descriptions of what’s going on in a video for people who can’t see it.

lo_vis_other.name: Specialized data compression
lo_vis_other.material: Algorithms can be inspired directly by accessibility needs, as showcased by a paper by Cavender et al. which looked at compressing videos with sign language in them to preserve readability of the sign language. By detecting and preserving a region of interest around the face and hands in the video, they were able to achieve better compression for sharing sign language videos.

lo_design.name: Universal design
lo_design.material:
Given the human focus of HCI, there’s reason to discuss design methods that take into account variations in ability.

Universal design has seven principles:

  • Equitable use
  • Flexibility in use
  • Simple and intuitive use
  • Perceptible information
  • Tolerance for error
  • Low physical effort
  • Size and space for approach and use (Appropriate size and space is provided for approach, reach, manipulation, and use regardless of user's body size, posture, or mobility)

Ability-based design also has seven principles:

  • Ability
  • Accountability (respond to poor performance by changing systems not users)
  • Adaptation
  • Transparency (users get awareness and ability to further customize adaptations)
  • Performance (systems track user performance to predict/adapt)
  • Context (sense context and anticipate effects on users’ abilities)
  • Commodity (don’t require expensive components)

lo_nlp_hist.name: Historical contributions of NLP
lo_nlp_hist.material: Historically, many parts of NLP were motivated by accessibility concerns. For example, speech synthesis and recognition are heavily intertwined and are important for producing audio or text captions for blind, low-vision, deaf, or hard-of-hearing users of technology.

lo_nlp_future.name: Future work for NLP
lo_nlp_future.material: In the area of machine translation, there is a particular need for translation to or from sign language. Since sign languages are full languages, interacting in another language, say by reading English, introduces cognitive load since it involves translating on the fly. This is an open problem that needs a lot of work, particularly since systems which place a costly monetary or mental burden on people who are deaf as they interact with people who are hearing are both unfair and unlikely to catch on. The difficulty of this problem is compounded by a lack of major corpuses of any sign languages, partly because video is a newer medium than text and partly because no written system has been widely adopted for any sign languages.

lo_robo.name: Assistive Robotics
lo_robo.material: One use of robotics is for assistive robotics. The field of accessibility is rich in providing inspirations for applications of robotics. One example would be a walker that can come when called or help navigate to a desired location (http://repository.cmu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3180&context=compsci)

lo_sec_trade.name: Trade-offs
lo_sec_trade.material: One thing that is always important to consider with security are the different trade-offs around it. Accessibility is one of them. Toolkits reduce the barriers to the design of graphical user interfaces, but accessibility parts of them often require full control of the interface in order to make user-specific changes. Unfortunately, this can also allow malicious applications to grab sensitive information. You can see an examination of this space in a work by Roesner et al.

lo_sec_metric.name: As a success metric
lo_sec_metric.material: Accessibility might be one of the metrics used to judge a system’s success. For example, many works have examined alternatives to passwords, given passwords’ numerous drawbacks. Some of these drawbacks involve accessibility, although some of the alternatives have been worse. This paper by Bonneau et al. surveys some of these alternative passwords.

lo_vis_vis.name: Taking into account visual disabilities
lo_vis_vis.material:
Students should know not just that many people have difficulty perceiving visual information but also some actions they can take to alleviate these difficulties. Audience members might be color blind, need higher contrast, or need larger text. There are tools available to check whether a visualization satisfies these constraints, such as Vischeck’s Color Blindness Checker.

However, sometimes a visualization is completely inaccessible, for example if it is a 2D picture and the audience member is blind. In that case, it is necessary to provide alt text. Alt text can be tricky but a good rule of thumb is that it should have accurate and equivalent content and function, be succinct, not redundant, and if a longer explanation is needed be organised so more important content comes first (drill-down). This is a more comprehensive reference.

lo_db_tools.name: Accessibility of tools
lo_db_tools.material: To interact with databases, one needs tools, which might or might not be accessible, and queries, which are programs, which might or might not be accessible. Many programming languages, including query languages, are nigh-incomprehensible when read aloud by a screen reader, which is the main mode of interaction available to people who are blind or low-vision. Additionally, there exist no good tools to convey tabular data to a screen reader so that blind or low-vision people can access it.

lo_db_cases.name: Accessibility in case studies
lo_db_cases.material:
If your course discusses schemas and representations of data and why making good ones can be hard to do, disability is one potential complex example. Is having a disability a binary yes or no? Does it involve selection from a list? How do you deal with new classifications or restructurings of old ones, like the move to shift Asperger’s and autism to an autism spectrum?

An example of an interesting database is Open Sidewalks, through the Taskar Center. It’s a geospatial database of sidewalk accessibility that might provide a good case study.

lo_c_intf.name: The command line as an interface
lo_c_intf.material: In many ways, what students encounter today at the command line has more similarities to screen readers than to the familiar notion of GUIs. As they come to terms with this new interface, this may be a useful comparison.

lo_c_hist.name: History of computing
lo_c_hist.material:
Many of these courses have some sort of “computers through time” lecture. Here are a few notable discoveries or inventions inspired by or for accessibility:

  • Telephones (1880) (“devising methods of exhibiting the vibrations of sound optically, for use in teaching the deaf and dumb.” (Fay, American Annals of the Deaf, 1887))
  • TTY (1960s) (precursor to texting; sent text over phone lines for Deaf or deaf communication)
  • Modem (1960s) (invented by Robert H. Weitbrecht, himself deaf)
  • Captioning (1972) (enable deaf viewers to read audio)
  • Optical character recognition (1974) (printed materials to machine-readable text)
  • Speech synthesis (1976) (motivated by need for people without sight to read)
  • Speech recognition (motivated by need for people without sight to enter text without hands)
  • Screen readers (1980) (allow non-visual access to computers; motivated by section 508 legislation)

lo_nw_hist.name: History of networking
lo_nw_hist.material:
Many networking achievements or protocols were inspired by accessibility concerns:

  • Telephones (1880) (“devising methods of exhibiting the vibrations of sound optically, for use in teaching the deaf and dumb.” (Fay, American Annals of the Deaf, 1887))
  • TTY (1960s) (precursor to texting; sent text over phone lines for Deaf or deaf communication)
  • Modem (1960s) (invented by Robert H. Weitbrecht, himself deaf)

lo_i_who.name: What is a programmer?
lo_i_who.material: Vast numbers of people program (men and women, of all races), and many of them have disabilities, even disabilities that might at first glance seem like complete barriers. For example, despite lacking the visual advantages provided by syntax highlighting and indentation, there are many programmers who are blind. Many IDEs these days have add-ons available to make them more accessible, and Quorum is a programming language that was designed to make sense when read aloud. By contrast, Java contains a lot of meaningful punctuation that either gets ignored by screen readers, or can only be read out by also reading out all meaningless punctuation.

lo_pl_syn.name: Accessibility of syntax
lo_pl_syn.material: One thing that isn’t often considered when designing a programming language is the accessibility of its syntax. From a speech synthesis perspective, most programming languages are not very coherent—when it comes to screen readers, the meaningful punctuation either gets ignored or drowned out in the meaningless punctuation. Quorum is a programming language that was designed precisely for accessibility, so it’s an exception.

lo_sw_tools.name: Tools for writing software
lo_sw_tools.material: Many IDEs have plug-ins that can make writing software easier for those with disabilities. For example, StructJumper is a plug-in for eclipse that takes advantage of code’s abstract syntax trees to provide blind programmers with hierarchical navigation of the code.

lo_sw_reuse.name: Code reuse
lo_sw_reuse.material: Accessibility frameworks are an excellent illustration of the benefits of code reuse, since they can take care of many of the accessibility concerns for you when used properly. For example, default buttons in an android app can expose information to the android screen reader without you having to write your own screen reader.

lo_sw_reg.name: Regulations around accessible software
lo_sw_reg.material: A lot of front-end software engineering is governed by regulations. WAI-ARIA provides web accessibility standards, while Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 is an example of a government regulation which concerns accessibility of information technology (IT) in the federal government.

lo_ast.name: Applications of Abstract Syntax Trees
lo_ast.material: The structure that ASTs convey about a program can be used to make code more accessible to blind programmers, by using that structure for navigation or reading code aloud. That’s precisely what an Eclipse add-on by Catie Baker, StructJumper, did.

lo_code_trans.name: Code translation
lo_code_trans.material: Additionally, while the main usage of compilers is to generate lower-level, more optimized code from higher-level code, compilers can also be viewed as translators. This can be helpful for accessibility if one language is highly inaccessible to screen readers but another is not. As another example, Scratch is a block language whose blocks have been translated into many languages. This allows people who don’t speak the same language to collaborate on coding projects.

lo_os_case.name: Cross-layer case study
lo_os_case.material: Accessibility frameworks are built across many layers of an OS since they need access to everything from input to application logic. Thus, they’re a good example of a part of an OS that spans many layers, and so violates the general layered architecture. For example, input may need to be transformed, to allow someone with a vision or mobility impairment to speak in text instead of typing. Or, output may need to be read aloud, for example by a screen reader, so that a blind or low-vision person can perceive it.

lo_ai_bias.name: Bias in AI/ML
lo_ai_bias.material: ML algorithms are (at most) as unbiased as their data sets. Accessibility barriers can play a role in this bias. For example, if an app’s star rating is inaccessible to screen readers, as Yelp’s is on their mobile app, blind or low-vision people can’t participate in ratings. More generally, if you’re trying to interpret user data in order to improve your product for them, if people without disabilities can’t even use your application, then that’s data you’re not getting, and that you may not even realize you’re not getting. Of course, there’s also societal bias around disabilities, which will be reflected in many datasets, from large text corpuses to medical data.

lo_embed.name: Examples
lo_embed.material:
Examples of embedded systems are all around us. Examples of embedded technology being used for accessibility are, too:

  • Speech recognition in a cell phone, which can benefit people with motor or vision impairments as well as everyone else, involves a mike and its placement as well the software required to translate audio into text
  • Cameras have also become more common as part of accessibility tools, such as to recognize the denomination of currency
